description: ISOLET (Isolated Letter Speech Recognition) dataset. 150 subjects spoke the name of each letter of the alphabet twice, generating 52 training examples from each speaker. Captures acoustic features for speech recognition tasks.

creator.name: Ron Cole
creator.affiliation: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Oregon Graduate Institute

creator.name: Mark Fanty
creator.affiliation: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Oregon Graduate Institute

donor.name: Tom Dietterich
donor.affiliation: Department of Computer Science, Oregon State University

feature_description: 617 acoustic features including spectral coefficients, contour features, sonorant features, pre-sonorant features, and post-sonorant features. All attributes are continuous real-valued scaled into the range -1.0 to 1.0.

instances_per_class.note: 3 examples are missing due to recording difficulties

use_case: Automatic speech recognition, speaker-independent letter recognition, speech processing research, acoustic modeling
data_collection: 150 subjects (grouped into sets of 30 speakers each) spoke the name of each letter of the alphabet twice in a controlled environment
advantages: Good domain for testing scaling abilities of algorithms, noisy perceptual task, speaker-independent evaluation possible
challenges: High dimensionality (617 features), computational complexity for some algorithms (e.g., C4.5 slower than backpropagation)
ethical_considerations: Dataset represents English alphabet pronunciation primarily from US speakers, may not generalize to other accents or languages

citations.author: M. Fanty and R. Cole
citations.title: Spoken letter recognition
citations.venue: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 3
citations.editors: R.P. Lippman, J. Moody, and D.S. Touretzky

citations.author: T.G. Dietterich and G. Bakiri
citations.title: Error-correcting output codes: A general method for improving multiclass inductive learning programs
citations.venue: Proceedings of the Ninth National Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-91)

original_source.publication: M. Fanty and R. Cole: Spoken letter recognition

dataset_history: Data Collection: 150 subjects (grouped into sets of 30 speakers each) spoke the name of each letter of the alphabet twice in a controlled environment
inference_notes: Challenges: High dimensionality (617 features), computational complexity for some algorithms (e.g., C4.5 slower than backpropagation). Advantages: Good domain for testing scaling abilities of algorithms, noisy perceptual task, speaker-independent evaluation possible. Use Case: Automatic speech recognition, speaker-independent letter recognition, speech processing research, acoustic modeling
